Award.AwardTitle: Linking and Unifying Atomistic and Continuum Mechanics Formulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
One formidable obstacle standing in the way of progress in multiscale simulation over the past decades is the lack of a concurrent atomistic-continuum methodology that allows waves, heat, and defects to pass through the atomistic-continuum interface. To meet this critical challenge, the classical statistical mechanical theory of transport processes is reformulated so as to unify atomistic and continuum descriptions of balance laws and to recast the mathematical representation of the governing laws to facilitate coarse-scale finite element simulation of discontinuous material behavior. It is anticipated that this research will lead to a new formulation of continuum mechanics that is equivalent to a fully atomistic model at the atomic scale and to classical continuum mechanics at the macroscopic scale, thus naturally leading to a concurrently-coupled atomistic-continuum methodology.

The new methodology promises to expand current atomistic simulation-based predictive capability from sub-micron- to sub-millimeter-sized materials, thereby enabling multiscale analysis of complex materials. It will not only impact the areas of continuum mechanics and multiscale simulation, but also new materials development. The research results will be integrated into existing mechanics courses, and will be used in the classrooms to facilitate understanding of multiscale materials behavior. Computer codes developed will be posted for public use and feedback. The PI will also use a Curie Lecture Series that brings in well-established female scholars to campus as role models for graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has established a mathematical formulation that links and unifies atomistic and continuum mechanics. The one single formulation applies to both atomistic and continuum models, reflects all possible dynamics on length and time scales from the atomic to the macroscopic, and can be used for a direct atomistic analysis at fine scales to a continuum analysis in coarse scales, thus naturally leading to a concurrent atomistic-continuum methodology. Building upon the finite element analysis method, we have also developed numerical methods to solve the multiscale formulation. The result is a new concurrent atomistic-continuum (CAC) simulation tool that can be used to simulate multiscale dynamic materials behavior, with no empirical assumptions, other than Newtonian mechanics and the interatomic potential, being ever needed for the simulation. The resulted CAC method has following distinctive features compared with existing mesoscale or concurrent multiscale simulation tools:

 (1)   The formulation explicitly includes the crystal structure of materials and the interaction of atoms in the formulation. By including the internal degrees of freedom of atoms within each lattice cell in the formulation, the CAC method can simulate crystalline materials that have more than one atom in the primitive unit cell, such as nonmetal materials, and reproduce both acoustic and optical phonon dynamics;

(2)   With a single, precisely formulated set of balance equations governing both atomic and coarse-scale finite element domains, the artificial numerical interface or handshaking region that limits most multiscale methods to consider only static phenomena is not needed;

(3)   With the only constitutive relation being the nonlocal interatomic force-displacement relation and with the new mathematic form of the governing equations, the compatibility requirement between elements that must be met in the finite element representation of local continuum mechanics can be removed; consequently, nucleation and propagation of dislocations and/or cracks can be simulated in the continuum region modeled by finite elements, as direct consequences of the formulation of the governing equations.

The capabilities of the CAC formulation and simulation tools have been demonstrated though reproducing the dynamic behavior of polycrystalline and single crystalline materials, and the interaction between phonons and grain boundaries as well as that between phonons and dislocations. Polyatomic materials that have been used for the demonstration include Si and SrTiO3, the latter is an ionic material and has a perovskite structure.
